solution.text:
By definition of a rational number , we know that any number
that can be represented in the form of \(\frac pq\) is called a rational number , where q is not equal to zero
If we take _{{trunc(Decimal(10)/3,6)}}_, it is a number that has the digits at the decimal place repeating after constant interval
this can be written in the form of \(\frac pq\) as \(\frac {10}3\)
Also if we take 2.125 it can be written in the form of \(\frac pq \) as \(\frac {17}8\), that is a rational number
so we can say all the numbers whose decimal digits terminates after a finite number is a rational number
By definition of a rational number \(\frac 24\) also represents a rational number
although to represent this number on number line we take it's equivalent rational number \(\frac 12\)

content.text: Which of the following statements regarding rational number are correct:

incorrect.text: digits at decimal places of a rational number is non repeating and non terminating

correct.text: Rational numbers terminates after constant number of decimal places
If in a number, digits at the decimal places repeats after regular interval, the number is a rational number.
\(\frac pq\) represents a rational number even if p and q have a common factor
